comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Date 1882-1891 from lack of Post Office clock (see note). 

I wonder what tall building the photographer was on?  And why?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I'm not sure if this is too far away, but note the grand entrance at 15[?] George Street, indicating a grand house, and the curious structure on the corner with James Street. Could it be a tower of some kind? see Sydney metropolitan detail series - Redfern, Sheet 2, 2nd ed. 1894 acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367360.html These two properties, 13-15 George Street, were situated where the Reconciliation Park now is. Whether they were the houses demolished in the 1980s to make way for the park is unclear (they may have already been demolished and replaced previously) - www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/aboutsydney/HistoryAndArchive...

comment.author: 39928977@N04
comment._content: When were these type of street lamps in use and also there are no electricity poles along the street.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I think you are in the right-ish position - but "why" has me flummoxed.  
There seems not to have been any drama in the 1880s over Redfern's water and sewerage (except for a few smelly drains) 
- the steam tramway to Botany was already in Redfern Street (1882) 
- most of the houses on the right (west) side of George Street seem to have gone since for light industry,  but this can't be a resumption / demolition photo as the 1894 map still shows the individual buildings 
- could be part of a P@%!&@#@ of the railway station and yards,  but why not use the Post Office clock tower or St Paul's Church for a better view?

Any ideas anyone?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It always amazes me to see how few trees there are in these old photos of the city and 'burbs.  It must have been so much hotter, dustier and windier.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: This is a Quite Interesting red herring - there was an 1881 manslaughter inquest held in the Star Hotel (see note) against William Bignell of 28 George Street (one of those houses on the right). He killed his wife with brandy. Read all about it! - ATCJ 17/09/1881 p.41 col.3 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/70960145

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
Curiouser and curisouer!
It is quite a stark image even bereft of people.
It looks like William Bignell didn't last much longer than his wife!
-AG

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Ha! I missed that extra para underneath in the newspaper,  about the unfortunate William.  I wonder if they lived in that VERY LOW house in the middle?  And their ghosts have haunted George Street, Redfern  ever since?  Hence the empty street . . . God-fearing folk kept well away . . .  [too much Nescafe, again].

comment.author: 84586104@N06
comment._content: Hi I used to work in a chocolate factory in Redfern in 1979 it was not to far from the post office. i cant find pic's of it anywhere, It was called Francis chocolate factory.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/84586104@N06] rosefromnz - it seems the Francis chocolate factory was at 1-7 Stirling Street, on the corners with William St and Short St. GoogleMapsStreetView - maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Stirling+Street,+Redfern,+New+S.... It looks like it has been redeveloped, and I have had no more luck in finding an old photo. I suggest contacting the City of Sydney via www.photosau.com.au/cos/scripts/home.asp - they seem to have photos of almost every building around Redfern c.1989 for a heritage study.

comment.author: 36080928@N02
comment._content:
...Im wondering about old pics of 73-75 George Street... can anyone help???

dolspics

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/dolspics] This 1887 map of the area shows that the original structure at 73-75 was set well back from the road, towards the back of the block acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367359.html By 1894 the structure had been extended acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367360.html I'll let you know if I find any photos. I'm working over the long weekend so will be a few days until I have time to undertake a proper search.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/dolspics] Here's a 1930s streetscape. Go to -> photosau.com.au/Cos/scripts/home.asp In Keyword search box, enter this image no. -> 032674 Your building will be on the right, in the stretch beyond Wells Street in the centre of the photo - I think perhaps the first large structure past the group of terraces? Not specifically of the building your after, but at least gives you a context. If you contact City of Sydney Archives they'll be able to give you a higher quality version of the image.

comment.author: 36080928@N02
comment._content:
...that's brilliant guys..all additional things you find will be welcomed.... I'm in the process of restoring the warehouse...knowing what the building looked like over the years will be important for maintaining the historical integrity especially when the DA is submitted ... we love the original features and want it all kept...

I'd love an old picture of the frontage....as far as I can tell it had a driveway where the trucks would pick up and drop off.... previous uses... wireless manufacturer (Duffy Radios), film studio and most recently Anglican church.... as I say ..would love as much historical info as I can lay my hands on...  

dolspics

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/dolspics] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] From the GoogleMapsStreetView it seems to me that the current building was built in the 1920s - early art deco mouldings, etc. Possibly rebuilt after a fire in June 1924 at Fotheringham's Ltd., millinery manufacturers - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16151820. Mr Jacob Fotheringham died two weeks after the fire - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/16154553

comment.author: 36080928@N02
comment._content:
....fascinating stuff..thanks so much...

comment.author: 36080928@N02
comment._content:
1880's - we can see old bricked up doorways / arched windows at rear which probably gave access to real lane as shown on the early plan

Fotheringhams  (Milliners – company registered1924)

Duffy Radio - 1933-1935

Peerless Manufacturing – 1932-39 (given the overlap with Duffy did Peerless make the Duffy radio?)

Australian Optical Industries before 1951

Still owned by AOI but permission granted for Film, Art, Photographic Studio - 1959

Anglican Church – June 1967

Warehouse Conversion - 2012

comment.author: 36080928@N02
comment._content:
now updated as follows;

1880's - we can see old bricked up doorways / arched windows at rear which probably gave access to real lane as shown on the early plan

Fotheringhams (Milliners – company registered1924)

Duffy Radio - 1933-1935

Peerless Manufacturing – 1932-39 (given the overlap with Duffy did Peerless make the Duffy radio?)

Crest Woodcraft and Plastics - 1942 (manufacturer of bomb shelters and protective screening for shopfronts)

Australian Optical Industries before 1951-1958

Still owned by AOI but permission granted for Film, Art, Photographic Studio - 1959

Anglican Church – June 1967

Warehouse Conversion - 2012
